5U_ByRcWog4GnOBkysaShw.text: Very very good food in terms of flavor and a nice bistro cafe atmosphere. It is a bit crowded however (tables clustered extremely close together) and one does need to book in advance. This could easily bump up to five stars on repeated visits and further menu exploration.

0fxA8YN_tbB38ORcr4Dk5Q.text: Delicious, flavorful, inexpensive. I'll definitely come back here when I'm in the area again.

jtGE8dEuc70J1LCVTGCIvg.text: Food is original and the setting is intimate. Pricey but as a one-off treat it's worth pushing the boat out. Definitely the place to go in London for a taste of authentic middle-eastern cooking.

RE4wJdjQdDEg0x8dGzK9Aw.text: Well-balanced tastes and interesting dishes, friendly and knowledgeable wait staff.It is a small restaurant and making reservations necessary for dinner.

iKQum9aqF4aK8zPaAl_thQ.text: Absolutely loved Honey & Co. Yes its small and cramped but the quality, tasty food more than makes up for the lack of space. We didn't choose the mixed mezze platter which was a regret ( will we will back) as it looked amazing. However our starters of falafel and fattoush were delicious.  Fresh, tasty and full of flavour. Mains were Greek Orzo and Shish Brick Lamb. Again, the combination of flavours were superb.   Huge fan of middle eastern cuisine and this was up there with the best of the best.

A0F9QXczBHzUiPa3QZmpEw.text: Very good restaurant. Small inside so there are two sittings in the evenings. We had the sharing platter to start, which in my opinion was the best bit. I then had the lamb with rice for my main which was a bit more filling than I expected!! But delicious. Enjoy!

ny38J2eRuGqsHNco4zGc_g.text: I love restaurants like these, small, intimate, not too pretentious, great food.We had the warm bread and the fig/whipped feta/ honey to startI had the cauliflower main dish and my fiancée the chicken with a parsley pomegranate salad.  We finished off with the cold cheesecake, probably the best cheese cake I've had.  Loved everything we had.  Great, warm service.  Wish we had time to go back here!

vAOiOLHG23xepepsvcZCzg.text: It took ages to get a booking but it was well worth the wait. The staff were friendly and attentive and they thoughtfully explained the menu. We chose to go with the "tasting menu" that came with a family style selection of mezze and a choice of main courses. There were four of us and we each chose a different entree and all were awesome! Try the prawns if they are on the menu as they were perfectly cooked, delicate, yet flavorful. The cold cheesecake for dessert lives up to the hype and a must-get!

UTSZjkapeAfkeiMTbZQW_A.text: Went here on the rave recommendation of a dear friend.  While a bit cramped in this cozy restaurant, the food was so amazing we didn't mind.  We ordered the Meze.  The food was spiced to perfection.   It's excellent, without at all being snooty.  The Charming Israeli chef/couple that own/run the place greeted the diners. We also found the dessert (a sticky bun) to be sumptuaous. Book ahead because it's that good.

X6B3ZOZK30rPalsx1xBchQ.text: this place had built a real following since opening last year. they've generated a real buzz with their marketing so we were excited to try it out. booked for saturday lunch, table was ready when we arrived. it's definitely pot-luck on who your neighbours will be, hopefully you won't get the "let's talk so loud about ourselves" types that ruin so many london restaurants. the reason I say this is that the tables are pretty damn close to eachother. they could probably lose 1 or 2 to make it more comfortable. food and service were both excellent. we had the meze selection and the lamb and beef mains. great flavours. and exceedingly full afterwards. would like to have tried the baked tomatoes and halloumi...looked superb. house red was ok, when will UK restaurants learn to make the house wine decent?!? I might also add that the serving of pitta bread was far too small. bit cheap on that front. decor wise its pretty basic, in fact why don't they put some more plants and colour into it like the washroom area? because there is no space!i've sounded pretty negative but we did really enjoy it. i suppose we just expected a bit more. def worth trying out.

dJup3YBJ3BbG3imCQer-Kg.text: DING DING DING DING.That's the bell sounding.That's the sound of excitement.The sound of discovery.The sound of London.That's the sound of another great place to eat, with authentic ethnic food, in unpretentious surroundings.Me and the missus met for lunch in a place equidistant from my work and hers. Warren St was that place. My old stomping ground, but how many of the good old places were still there? Not many. But the missus had read about this place and with us both liking a bit of middle eastern we gave it a bash.Small room. Tables so close that essentially you're sharing. noise bounces off the bare walls and floors making it almost uncomfortably loud. But there's a good buzz emanating from the place and some good smells emanating from the kitchen downstairs. So we wait patiently and are soon rewarded with a tiny table for two.Busy waitress recommends the mezze to share to start. She sits down for a sec to impart the information with a wink. Formal it ain't. We see that next door has ordered the same (not hard, it's so close you could practically sniff it to your side of the table) and it looks bloody delicious, so we go for it.What comes are some truly delightful small plates. Carrot rounds marinated in vinegar and cumin. Deep fried cubes of cheese are perfect. A nicely balanced chick pea salad. baba ganoush that tasted of the grill. Proper olives. Freshly done pitta bread which we simply had to have more of. I don't think they charged us for our greed either. What a start. This food is cooked not just with skill, but with love. That you could tell. It couldn't get better could it?I ordered chicken dumplings in broth as a main and the missus ordered the hummus topped with ground meat.What arrived was just a delight. The chicken dumplings were sitting in a light clear broth which smelled like only a carefully made, home cooked broth could. And floating on top were some beautiful flowers and green leaves which not only looked wonderfully pretty but tasted damn good to. The whole thing was a picture. A winning spring dish if ever I've had one. I would describe it as memorable, I really would. The hummus was creamy and the minced lamb on top nicely spiced with the usual cinnamon and things and lots of deep red oil to raise the cholesterol and the enjoyment. Not memorable in the way the chicken dumplings were, but totally moreish and satisfying. We wiped each plate clean with the pitta bread that came with the hummus until the plates were ready for the next customers. The two of us shouted our appreciation to the ever so friendly waitress as the noise levels rose still further with happy eaters blasting away in this great place.We walked out with the flavours still dancing away in our mouths. Sorry to be crude but I can't find a better way to say it. This place doesn't fuck around. You come in, you eat proper street food from half way round the world, you leave with your belly full and your wallet only a little lighter. As I wandered back to work I was reminded one again why London is the greatest city in the world.

ave5WRMeIzKKvFf1Y_wI2A.text: The manager here is terribly rude. We had a table for three booked until 12pm, and arrived 4 people. He said its ok, gave us an extra table but said we can only use it until 11:30. At 11:30 he came to our table and asked us to leave . We asked to use the one table we had booked until 12, or at least finish the coffee we ordered 10 mins before, but he said NO. Although no one was waiting for the table (?!). The food was only OK, but we will never return again. It was a disgrace.

0qJGdbvjcspbdly7gFqWfw.text: Honey and Co is the best deal in london. Reasonably priced, outstanding food -- especially the desserts of which I recommend the cheesecake, the lemon drizzle, and the poppyseed cake. The setting is nothing to write home about but the staff makes up for in charm what the physical surroundings lack.

3A6dpVFNK4Hfa-yldHeCgg.text: Vastly over rated.  The venue was uncomfortably tight but unlike its contemporaries, Flat Iron and Pitt Cue, you're left wondering why you put up with it because it's neither great value or tasty.  Seasoning folks - every dish needed more flavour and seasoning.  Drinks were lovely.  They made bland hummus - how is that possible??  I would say it's more dabbling in Middle Eastern flavours than truly Middle Eastern or even Middle Eastern inspired.

FDeE3JmirqdtvRaBpgGZ5w.text: The food here is creative. It serves a few middle eastern dishes with a modern twist. The major drawback is their relatively high prices. I had the lamb shawerma which came with a small side of salad for £15.5 which is probably the most expensive shawerma I ever had and heard of. The place is small and cozy which is a plus. I recommend this place if you don't mind the prices.

fy1xTAJTz2bgFxQufpF7YA.text: These people sure know how to combine spicy and not so spicy food. Little expensive but totally unique

zbgDXbryUwGmrXuTlbB_eg.text: I would love to say that I tried their food, however we got ushered off the premises by clueless and rude staff members. I arrived on a Tuesday evening with a friend to catch up over a meal, we arrived and were told that we would have to wait. The room was very cramped for a restaurant. We waited outside and for 5-10 minutes when we were told that there were no spaces. As we left we saw a couple leaving, so we asked whether we could have their seats after them, the staff member said yes. So we waited longer. As we finally went to sit down we were asked whether we wanted to order all 3 courses. After saying that we were only planning on one or two courses  we were rudely told(not asked) to leave to make room for other guests. There were no other guests arriving, nor anyone waiting. I'm not sure what we did to deserve such abhorrent treatment but we certainly won't be going back to find out, nor to find out what their food is actually like, although I have heard good things! Possibly one for the foodies, but not those who wish to have a pleasant dining experience with kindly members of staff.

NDlPDkLeQ3IzRR5TzpNtaw.text: So I don't often leave a review but given the quality of the food and service I had to leave a comment.  Everything we had was amazing from the mez to the chicken to the kefta.  Our server Rachel was very knowledgable and friendly.  Reminded me a lot of the upper west side brunch spots in NYC that are so hard to find in Europe.  Would definitely love to visit again and a definite recommendation for my friends visiting London.

ZbDF6nbosyzWn3ADvRHYYw.text: I had a fantastic meal here with a couple of friends recently. The restaurant is small and has a cosy, welcoming atmosphere. The food, all regional dishes, was really tasty and offered good value for money. I will definitely be going back.

Xm_5cCR3hNVfmJQljQcmcg.text: I was so excited to try this place but was sadly disappointed.  Our mains were just ok but for the price it definitely stung.   15 quid for a simple ground lamb stew with 2 pieces of eggplant and a tiny side of cherry tomatoes?   I will say the cheesecake could possibly be the best thing I have ever eaten.

FgOEezp4lYECb5T-daUqoA.text: A knafe, or kadaifi in Greek, is a pastry filled with goat cheese topped with a sugar syrup, rose water, and pistachios served warm.It's the perfect dessert for when you want something a little sweet, but not too sweet.  The goat cheese balances out the sugar syrup, while the pastry and pistachios give a nice crunch.  The rose water was just enough to be fragrant, but not overwhelming.The only downside was having to make the decision of what to eat!  (We deliberated for a while!)  But I guess that's just another excuse to go back!

iQRzsCFdHbigaJdG2J4YSw.text: Small, friendly, almost neighbourhood restaurant, and it's excellent. Really, quite excellent. I've been twice now, it's great to go with friends - excellent atmosphere, and had an early dinner both times. The mezze platter is the way to go, and it changes seasonally, as it should! As of last weekend there is a wonderful feta and watermelon combination! Wine list is simple and solid, the house white pairs well with most everything, though I couldn't help thinking how great a cold/salty/petrol-ly retsina would be too. There's a fantastic chilled red desert wine that's well worth trying if you get round to it! The mains rotate with seasons - I had an exceptionally tender grilled ox tongue back in May, which was sadly not there when i returned, but there's a solid shawarma, and grilled pomegranate molasses chicken that turned out to be rather great alternatives. They're not the biggest mains, but after grazing on the mezze with lots of time for idle banter, you'll be sufficiently suffonsified... But don't let that stop you trying the desserts - the standout among them is the cold cheesecake. A not too sweet, not too rich, and (probably) ricotta based dessert with a fried Kadalf pastry (think crispy baklava) base covered with honey and pistachios. A wonderful way to finish the meal. It's in a quiet location, on a part of Warren street not really near too much else. I would book, and then eagerly wait in anticipation of a great meal. Go with friends, you won't be disappointed.

fIbNglUU0zIc1D2vOuei-Q.text: This place was absolutely fantastic, and everybody knows it - they were packed at 230 pm on a Monday!  It's quite a small restaurant so be prepared to wait, and know that it'll be worth it.  We sat at barstools in the window - the only seats left in the place!  Everything on the menu looked fantastic and we waited eagerly.  Service was friendly but a bit slow (small kitchen I expect), the one thing we weren't keen on was we were asked to keep our water bottle on the floor - I guess having it in the window would not be a nice aesthetic for the passersby?  Come on, relax.They have a set lunch menu, I forget the price - £15 maybe?  It was only a few pounds more than a lunch entree so if you are hungry and want to try more things, it's absolutely worth it.  If you do the set menu, everyone has to do it in your party.  With the set menu you get mezze for the table and then everyone picks an entree.  The mezze were amazing - pickled carrots, gorgeous creamy hummus, pistachio cherry tabbouli, little cheesy pastry things, kalamata olives, pitta bread, and surely something else I'm forgetting but trust me when I say it was all fantastic.  Such a treat!  We scraped the bowls clean.  Everything was not only very fresh and clearly homemade with love, but unique.  Even the hummus was superior to the ordinary sort.  Nothing we had was just average food that you could get at any Mediterranean place.  It was all very inspired, creative, divine.For my entree, I got the sea bream and artichoke tagine in preserved lemon sauce with couscous.  So unique!  The fish was flaky and delicate, the sauce tart and rich.  I tried some of the lamb shwarma which was outstanding (reminiscent of pulled pork - pulled lamb!?) and the meat hummus was also delightful.  My parents had fresh lemonade and elderflower iced tea and said the drinks were just perfect.I would recommend that anybody come here in a heartbeat.  I don't think you'll find anything else like it in town!

TptTDsy4PAlmQhouiApYww.text: Pretty great! The food is almost too rich (go hungry) and the only criticism is that the place is small so always full! Will return soon

kCO6QtTNWzdVrJcFgLV1BQ.text: Went to a birthday party here where the whole restaurant was booked (not too difficult as the place only holds approx 20-25 people) its a quaint little place with a little bar at the back. The girls serving were all really good and friendly,  the food came out well and they managed to make sure that every one got their pre-ordered meal! Drinks were kept well topped up through out the night.The food was all good a selection of starters to share that included bread with oil, falafels, pickled carrot (my favourite), melon and feta, aubergines and humus to name a few. A small criticism might be that there was actually too many starters as I strugged to get through my whole main (dont normally complain about too much food but felt it just ruined my main that I would have liked to have finished)I had the lamb Shawarma,  can't remember if I have had this meal anywhere else but it was good!! Well seasoned and a decent portion (if I had less starters!) Of the other 4 mains on offer one other was lamb and there was a fish dish and a beef selection.  All were well received although I heard mixed reviews on the fish. I managed to get a few mouthfuls of the beef which was good but would have seen me a little bit bored of eating the same thing if I had chosen it.So it all seems good! ! Why not 4 *??? Just a few minor things: The AC was broken and packed out the place got very warm. There is only one shared toilet which with 25 people sharing it required some strategic planning to not end up quing for too long. Lastly you can see into the kitchen from the bathroom area, its not unhygienic and I appreciate its a working kitchen but I would have liked to seen it a bit cleaner and tidy.It seemed a litrle pricey but we did a split bill and I cant be sure that bsome people ordered more drinks,  so I would definitely eat here again if I was in the area.

UIigXjavGWp9j_dEVt9wbw.text: Om nom nom! I was brought here by a friend who had clearly been here before (so much so that he knows the wait staff). We sat down and caught up because I hadn't seen him in so long. Anyway, I'm not a huge connoisseur of Middle Eastern food, and I didn't understand a thing on the menu, but HOT DAMN was it good. We had a couple of amazing starters (Hummus and pita breads) and the Plum Tea (mine had these rose-like petals in it) was delightful, albeit a little dent was made in my masculinity for drinking tea with flowers in it. We shared a main course of pulled lamb and on pita bread. And probably the best pulled lamb I've had... well, ever.I'd say, go. It's totally worth it.

bIwhE9owfJ4eXZldMMdvHA.text: Amazing food and drinks highly recommended. We had the lunch time set menu and found it to be alot of food (and im pregnant) thought it was reasonable for 15. Lovely iced teas and cakes are amazing!  Lemon drizzle is my favourite. They also have outside seating so if you love people watching like me it's the perfect place. Its very small inside max 10 tables so book in advance!!

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Lamb dish with pomegranate

OAqovkc-xuyoLH7pD3sN3Q.text: We were staying nearby on our holiday, and found this place on yelp.  The service and food were both fantastic.  If I were a local I'd be a regular, for sure. Yum!

DGRp5A3M-PeEpFJw6WDvYQ.text: Went for brunch on Saturday and enjoyed it thoroughly Everything was fresh, healthy and super tasty with creative flare, taking the brunch to the next level with home made hummus(best I had in London) Arabic coffee and exotic egg dishesThe atmosphere is cosy and friendly Can't wait to go back

A7Qxa6UHtg0jKIAHS5bTfQ.text: Really savory middle eastern food with a refined twist. Make sure to try the desserts

4PYr9eMZYhaF2TUNuUH-SQ.text: They brought us blankets on the patio when it was cold out, and the food was spectacular. So glad I took my family to eat here!

Flx7Z4UA25UrcgMk0ILtzA.text: Was interested having some good old Med food so ventured in with Honey & Co, which came from a recommendation by Jay Rayner of the Guardian. Started the lunch with a plum juice, which was very refreshing. For starters, I ordered the chicken liver baklava with grape molasses. Quite an innovative mix of a pate-type paste with the sweetness of the baklava. My initial surprise of the amalgamation of flavours, gave way for an excessive sweetness in my mouth and I had leave the dish midway. My girlfriend ordered the Jerusalem-styled falafel, which was quite average; a surprise as you'd expect Honey & Co. to get the basics right. For the main course, I ordered the Mushahan, which is a slow-cooked chicken baked on flat bread. This was the saving grace for the lunch as the pomegranate and currants really added an interesting twist to it.I won't be going back in a hurry but go there for an exotic take on traditional dishes and great service.

GVCkybYCvTrTBJmmhE6YzQ.text: I was thrilled to finally eat at to Honey and Co, a charming Middle Eastern inspired cafe run by Israeli husband and wife chef team. It didn't disappoint at all food wise. It was delicious. The best value meal would be to opt for the set menu, although we didn't go that route sharing a starter, 2 mains and a dessert. The hands down favourite of the evening was the brisket dumpling main course. I'm not sure exactly what was in it but it was a sort of salt beef ravioli if you will, in a creamy sauce with currents. Whatever it was, it was absolutely delicious - amazing, well balanced and scrummy, unique flavours.As well as delicious food, the staff were also really helpful. I felt I was at really friendly family owned restaurant, and I can't wait to come back and try breakfast.Decor wise, it's quite small and simple - more of a cafe. The emphasis is on the food and service, rather than style.  Tables are tightly packed next to other tables.  It was a little bit difficult to get into my seat as it's quite crammed at dinner time -  so do book. They offer you either the 6pm or 8pm sitting, as it's quite a cosy restaurant and they've limited capacity.  I have to admit, dinner service prices are a bit high for a cafe experience but if you love Middle Eastern flavours definitely worth checking it out.

yo8vmKpb6wTRrNcklRYhGQ.text: Loved it!  Great assortment of food and the desert was fantastic...we had the cheesecake per suggestion of a friend and it didnt disappoint.  Very, very nice spot.

frAbhfG9iMLQfmnjsLDzxA.text: Tiny little restaurant with great food, great service, and great atmosphere. Able to book for groups and have a reasonably priced set menu. The shared starters are absolutely delicious.Highly recommend.

uVRqJXDkG2Th_uLJRvsrNg.text: I love ottolinghi and always complain about having to go all the way to Kensington, Notting Hill, or Islington in order to get good takeout - always envy friends who live or work in these areas However, when I found out from Yelp newsletter that Honey&Co is a new place with a similar concept and very close to where I live, I was thrilled Strong points: 1- location- I think starting a business on that almost dead street is genius and you can tell that a place like that was needed from the number of people dominating the place all the time. 2- decor- so cute I love how they display bowls filled with aubergine and courgettes and the variety of cakes on the window3- food selection- good number of dishes and very tasty Low point - being from the Middle East I know the traditional way of presenting/ cooking those dishes which is at Honey and Co has nothing to do with the original dishes It is a great place to go for lunch or desert or mint tea or hummus And the hostesses are very very friendly Prices are reasonable too

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Chicken salad
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Tweaked tabbouleh version
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Mint tea

WoO0hWoh9hxjvwArn9Y-0g.text: Tucked away towards the end of Warren St. is some deliciousness. We had a variety of dishes and everything was light, fresh, and fulfilling. They had some interesting twists on traditional dishes and one thing is for sure.we devoured all of it. The restaurant is quite small so reservations are suggested.

mxAlh4JPykxykj4RP8cvvQ.text: Read about this in Time Out last week. I have been there twice since then.It was started by a few former Ottolenghi chefs, who have brought a similar taste and trendiness to Warren Street. The food is light and healthy with an emphasis on vegetables, and often with a delightful splash of yogurt or feta. The violet aubergine bourek was awesome, as was the special lamb shwarma with pomegranate seeds. The waitstaff are very friendly and accommodating.Ask for their iced tea of the day - so far have had orange+orange blossom and plum, rose+violet. Would go back in a heartbeat. However, it's very small and only open for lunch so you need a reservation if you're coming at rush hour.UPDATE: It's now open for dinner, but you still need a reservation as it's EXTREMELY popular!

ZX2Lu_9ARUWUWBOBSJo6dQ.text: Place has an amazing atmosphere. Food was great, if even a bit too pricey. My main reservation would be the waiting time- the place is tiny, and so you can expect to wait quite a bit to be seated.

My_ZvEn47C_g7zTgYkL3pA.text: I have the first cookbook written by Honey & Co.  I have been very excited to try this restaurant since it's opening in 2012. Since the opening, a second cookbook was released. The very small Middle Eastern-cafe is very crowded, seating is uncomfortably tight, and the decor is simplistic.  Initially, the only table that was available was outside in the cold and darkness. Fortunately, inside seating became available but it so cozy that you can almost read your neighbor's texts. The service was initially welcoming. The walls are stacked with jams, chutneys, coffee, cookbooks, and rose water. The back counter had a delicious presentation of desserts. I ordered the "Winter Set" mezze which was fresh, colorful,  and fabulous. I had sliced cinnamon falafel with tahini; creamy hummus; creamy saffron pears with walnuts; aubergene bourrkka; minted courgette with yogurt; hot tomatoes; pickles & kalamata olives; a sampling of home-made breads and olive oil. My main entree was the Madfunia which was a slow-cooked Chicken with chestnuts, golden raisins, and topped with a crisp Kadhafi crust. After my third piece of bone in my chicken, I was finished. My neighbors and I waited forever for our checks and to leave. I loved the appetizers and I was genuinely enjoying my meal and the restaurant.  I, however, was disappointed with the quality of my entree. The lack of service at the end of my meal and the lack of space took my score from a four-star to a three-star rating. They also have Honey & Spice, a food store, a few doors down the street. honeyandco.co.uk

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom

HcLavg9DrbtTXJXPIj_gVA.text: Beautiful, delicious, delightful staff. Just an absolute pleasure for breakfast.

xF4-svN7NcvB2_B_Dxr0Tg.text: Some places deserve to have a cookbook or two. This is one of them. Since its opening a few years ago, Honey and Co has followed Ottolenghi's tradition of modern middle eastern fare in a less opulent manner. You get the sense that everything here came from someone's kitchen, the product of love and family, designed to show off the best of its ingredients, rather than overwhelm with complexity or pretension. Freshly baked counter pastries and cakes are usually dripping with honey, rose or pistachios. Savory meguese sausages and baked eggs are accompanied by home-made harissa (slightly sweat inducing, salty and lime-noted, as it should be). The service is always friendly and loyal locals mingle with far-flung foodies like me. If you succumb to one of their cookbooks, the good news is that their recipes travel well and deliver a result (almost) as good as the originals you will find when you (inevitably) return. Sweet!

lUrmLIMhYKxV8fD8kZW38w.text: Came here for "brunch" at 12:30 but the breakfast menu stops at around 11:30, so ended up having a very nice lunch instead. For a starter, I got a tomato and aubergine salad, which was quite refreshing and came with a yogurt type of sauce. Then as a main, I got grilled sea bream, which was served with vegetables and beans, kinda the type that you would eat as a seafood lunch at a beach town, except that we were really indoors in a Mediterranean restaurant in London. It was apparently new on the menu, but very high quality food.However, the settings were a bit less than ideal... I booked ahead of time by emailing the restaurant, and they responded promptly and I got the reservation without a problem. Btu the restaurant is really cramped and I was with a guy that was 6'4" and he was clearly uncomfortable with the lack of leg room at a 2-person table. It was also necessary to move tables just so that I could get into my seat, to give you an idea of how little room there is. So definitely keep that in mind... would be very difficult to come in big groups and with anyone that is not a very good friend or family!

Kr0EyF8jCZOTftSnnf8hsA.text: One of the best meals I have ever had! We walked in on a Thursday night. It was booked but the hostess offered us a spot by the window in 20/30 minutes. We came back and they just so happened to have a cancelation on one of their reservations! We had the sharing option that blew us out of the water. It came with an entree each. Our server was delightful! He was knowledgeable, attentive and entertaining :) we had such a lovely time. The cheese cake dessert was said to be the 4th best dish in London and probably my life. It was sweet, salty, creamy and crunchy; topped with almonds and blueberries. A dessert that evoked emotion... my girlfriend and I are both foodies and like to find 'off the beaten track' places to eat when we travel. This place goes down in the books for us. Make a reservation and go!

DB5oET3kiwwa13jRENPwaQ.text: This restaurant is my favourite in London for brunch. It's so unique and different. The first time I came here I ordered the Sabich, which is basically a friend egg and aubergine. This was bursting with so much flavour! I can't even describe it - it's definitely something I strongly recommend. The next time I got poached legbar eggs in yogurt. This was also good but there could be more bread! Strongly recommend! Wish it wasn't so expensive, but it's a great place to treat yourself.

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Poached legbar eggs, spinach, yogurt, potato bread
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Sabich - aubergine, tahini, pita. So delicious!

f3I_xlf5aPootz_rueYo_w.text: All I can say is- wow. I read about this place being a top notch Mediterranean breakfast joint and I'm more than impressed. The shashouka was just the right level of savory, spicy, and tangy. With a warm piece of bread on the side, the dish truly made my morning.

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Authentic shashouka

CwM-MBWj56dp9b1U3TYfCA.text: This is a cracking little place to visit. I work at Pall Mall Barbers around the corner from them and try to pop in her for breakfast. They do a salted milk bun with jam, (posh jam on toast) that tastes great. The orange juice is freshly squeezed and the coffee tastes great to. I personally live to go somewhere with a bit of character like this rather than a Pret or Costa where  your just a number. 10/10

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. One lump or 2

AHwXfoUf599JHwcLqjPoYA.text: It's a small place and I have tried several time to book a table and no luck. Decided to come at 5:30 and they gave me a table that was booked for 6:30. Everything is delicious. Dessert is a must here. Be sure to save room for it.

jNLdIgAqTis1CH2EI-hpvA.text: I'm into this place.  Tiny, so hard to get a table.  I had tried booking many times and it is a hard place to just rock up because it is so small.  Come hungry.  The meze is awesome--such a treat to try all the different things.  They mix the menu up by month but the lamb salad was delicious and the dumpling soup was incredible.I would eat the tahini ice cream cookie sandwich any day of the week.  It was amazing.  Ottolenghi taught his staff well.

VcWXKUGa5r7RuGHx58AoNQ.text: Top-notch middle-east cuisine!!! I had great expectations about this place, and definitely it was worth to try their food. I tried a kind of marinated beef that was outstanding, the lamb chops and falafel (superb!). Of course, I also tried an outstanding desert! The food was excellent. Perfectly cooked! But there were a couple of things that I want to point out (and hopefully it will be help for the owner/manager/staff). First, the lamb chops were perfectly cooked. However, the meat was a little bit hard. In other words, the lamb was not tender enough. I am not saying it was bad lamb or that it was super hard. I just was expecting it to be more tender. Second, I truly appreciate that the staff was very nice, smiling all the time and super friendly. However, I tried to call their attention twice, and I took me a while, since the waitresses were chatting with some friends, or talking among themselves (for instance, I was holding a plate for a while waiting for someone to take it; note that the tables are tiny, so an extra plate on the table is a pain in the back). Again, they were friendly and helpful, but I think they should keep an eye on customers first. Overall, excellent experience. By they way, the decoration is beautiful! Regarding prices: not cheap, but not crazy expensive.

g33plXrSh9g2msoLmyLnGA.text: this place is a little on the expensive side but really very delicious food. Nicely presented. Good sensible portion sizes and very lovingly made

trgVsnB6RCD0NOpvehijwg.text: This place could be so much more if it would be a little bit bigger and had more waitstaff. It was my first time there and I didn't realize how popular the place is. I was seated at the bar/window, which was lucky considering I didn't have a reservation. I am a small person and yet I felt like an elephant in a china shop in that place. They really shouldn't cram that many tables in that small space. It took a while for my order to be placed considering the restaurant was not full yet. I ordered the lemonade (seriously good) and the chicken dish that reminded me of an empanada. The food was delicious and the low rating isn't for the food. After my meal was delivered, no one came to check if everything was ok, I would have loved to have ordered another lemonade. I had to ask for the check and to see the dessert menu. In the end I decided to take the dessert to go ... because I probably would have waited forever for it to be delivered (which is a shame, because I really wanted to try the cheesecake confection ). My bill was brought and after waiting quite a bit of time I had to go the counter in order to get change. I'm not a picky/particular person, but it's not an inexpensive place. For those prices, I shouldn't have to be chasing you down and made to feel like I was an afterthought or an inconvenience. The food was delicious though.

svAavafG-e4Qpm5ujaj00Q.text: What a gem! I just got around to this restaurant after more than a year on my list and now I regret the wait! It is very small, so I recommend reservations. I didn't expect it to be so busy on a Friday mid-afternoon, but the wait was over 45 minutes and we elected to eat outside. I had the BBQ aubergine, which exceeded all expectations. It had some sort of tahini filling that was positively luscious, all nicely complemented by the jeweled rice salad. My dining companion had the Patlican, which she also loved. The only disappointment was the coffee, but that can be forgiven. Catching a chill outside was totally worth it for this amazing food.

CMZ6iMVbrjo6eVJ8WbPRQA.text: So was a bit of a difficulty reserving a place and even then it was a bit cosy/difficult. Shakshuka was okay but a little expensive and service wasn't amazing; rather grudgingly took my friends order back with an odd and unnecessary comment. Still, if you find yourself in this part of town you probably can't do much better.

2Jzo9FqIOt7MHidc1t-9qA.text: Lovely family run restaurant - small and friendly with some very interesting and tasty food. Home made specialties are on the menu and they also have their own cookbook and cakes to buy on the go. Not the biggest portions or cheapest food but lovely flavours and unique options. Must book in advance due to popularity. I was particularly wowed by the lemon pudding I had (pic attached) which was delicious, with great texture and so so more-ish.

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. My favourite - lemon pudding
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Almond pudding (flourless) with salted caramel sauce
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Chicken parcel - one of the most popular dishes

Dgbm66J6JY24bCzGUr-Qag.text: Came for lunch and got the lunch special - selected mains and appetisers for the table for about £15. Great value. Got the falafel and the lamb as main dishes and both were great. Service was not bad. Place is tiny and tables are cramped but was still a pleasant experience overall.

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Lamb main with some appetizers

RVB7ezyGSYpVsp7A7DylkA.text: Excellent food. Spot is quite cozy but it is also rustic and charming. The appetizers, entrees, and desserts were all quite lovely.   Really looking forward to coming back soon.

hxBWWLMGi0XRGEAZYvW2cA.text: My Friend introduced me to this place and their brunch is inspired by middle eastern cuisine. Love their shabshukas which offer more of a kick that your usual tame breakfasts, and they cook everything to perfection. If there's one thing you should come here for, it's the cheesecake, which is a little expensive, but completely instagrammable due to its unique look and when you bite into it, there you'll discover the perfect blend of sweet and salty and you'll mouthgasm your way to heaven. Yes yes and yes again!

xnyGFGRZvFjtJWTKJjnTdQ.text: Amazing spot! The service is great and the staff is so nice. I came in on a busy Saturday night with no reservation. The host said that she would call me when they had something open but I explained I didn't have a working phone because of travel. She said to go to the bar next door and have a drink and she would come over and get me. No more than 20 minutes later, she came and got me and I was seated. You can tell that so much care goes into making the food. Not only does it look beautiful but it tastes amazing. I don't think you could go wrong with any of the dishes. Because they were very busy, they had to quickly turn over the tables in an hour, so I had to have the cold cheese cake to go. It was so delicious and definitely worth trying!

5qTG0Uv_z4NFNBsResn73Q.text: So delicious! I got the shawarma: tender lamb, chewy burnt pita, yogurt, shredded cabbage, halved cherry tomatoes, mint, and pomegranate. Did take away and was headed to the park with food in hand (and a slice of chocolate babka) in ~15 minutes. Flavors were excellent and the staff was helpful and friendly. I went around noon and it was pretty packed inside and out, but the weather was perfect for brown bagging it and finding my own place to indulge nearby. Would be a go to if I lived in London. Highly recommend!

O-IMSaNpdRIePw9qVkd20A.text: (Please note that I only had coffee and dessert here, not their main)What a charming place, well worth seeking out.  You can always tell when the owners/management care about their establishment - and there is no greater turn-off, no matter how beautiful the surroundings or how good the food - if that attentiveness is not there.The staff cares.  They want you to enjoy your meal, and will answer your questions about ingredients, methodology, etc.They are famous, with reason, for their 'deconstructed' (or modern) take on the cheesecake: a lovely feta/cream cheese cloud atop a crispy baked kataifi (shredded filo pastry).  For perfection's sake, they drizzle thyme flavored honey on top and add lovely toasted almonds and a seasonal fruit (in this instance, blueberries).  This alone is worth the visit.As you can see from my pics, they sell their cookbooks on the premises, as well as homemade jam, Turkish coffee, other goods.  It can get hectic and you must absolutely make a reservation for a proper meal.  Don't walk, run!Also, on a side note, they are also known for their babka - very hard to find in London - which is a delicious sweet braided bread, often made with chocolate or poppy seeds.  I overheard another customer say she made a special trip just for that.

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Turkish coffee with cardamom
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Wonderful assortment of baked goods, with their chocolate babka in the lower left corner
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Cold cheesecake, kadaif pastry (different spellings of this throughout Middle Eastern cooking), thyme flavored honey

63VHwgwLzvXre5h423tucw.text: The lamb shawarma was super delish. You could definitely tell the meat wasn't sketchy. It was so tender and the pomegranate seeds were a nice touch. The pastries we had, on the other hand, were pretty flaccid. We had a lemon poppyseed cakes and a lemon cake with frosting, both of which were so sweet I almost retched. But the environment is quite nice, casual, and cute. Would recommend!

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Meh.
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Fleeky.

_ZrVnHzSGhb6cWKu6k7uow.text: After much anticipation, I went to Honey and Co for brunch. Brunch is serious business, so a place that serves it must do justice. Sadly, this place just didn't do it for me. I found the menu uninspiring frankly. Also, it is a tiny space, with tables cramped together. Noise levels are high. Clearly it is a very popular but I wouldn't go back to this place.

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Sticky bun with pistachio and sour cherries - Amazingly moist, sumptuous flavour and served on a tile!!!

Ja4xippxE7luU8u6ISDFrQ.text: Honey & Co. is one of the best meals I've had in London. From the exquisite starters - perfectly fried falafels, rich hummus - to the excellent service, to the mains that awoke my senses with surprising new flavors, I loved every bite. The aubergine was extraordinary - a must order. But the cheesecake stole the show - perfectly fluffy and unique with a hint of saltiness from the feta and crunch from the almonds with the sweetness of their namesake honey. Perfectly unexpected, perfectly delicious. I would highly recommend Honey & Co.

VbgBaCu2EYUQg80YD335xw.text: I love everything about this place. Service is always super friendly and efficient (we have managed to eat there several times in under 1h without feeling rushed at all), the atmosphere (basically like being at home, but without having to do the dishes), and most importantly the food! The homemade drinks are always stellar (especially the iced teas), the food is perfectly balanced and has just the right amount of spices and warmth and freshness to it. And the cakes, oh the cakes... Just thinking about it makes me hungry! A lovely place for breakfast, lunch and dinner (and they take bookiiiiiiiiiings!!)

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Beef kofta at Honey & Co
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Pistachio baklava at Honey & Co

E9o7o6mY8y_fS1QaSCvdfw.text: My husband and I live in Southern California and are exposed to middle eastern food and love it. When we accidentally came across this place, we were delighted. Authentic food and friendly staff specially Elisabeth (Eli) who was extremely warm and attentive. We will be talking about this place with all our friends and relatives back in the USA.

kuQL6bN4Fns_CabbptLuLQ.text: I had heard some good things about Honey and Co and gave it a try over the Christmas period. The venue is close to Warren Street tube (as the address would suggest) and is essentially a small cafe. We had a reservation which was handy because we would not have got in without it. The food was top quality, I would recommend going for a set menu which allows you to try the mezze, that was the best part of the meal. The Christmas set menu came in at £26.50 per person without dessert. Well worth a trip.

_4-0NaDHLPXBC9QFyUHa3g.text: Someone had recommended their cheesecake to me and I was not disappointed. It was honestly one of the best cheesecakes I've ever had. A bit pricey at £6 something but I would say it was worth it. It's light and fluffy, which is hard to achieve with cheesecake, with notes of honey. Blueberries and I think a sprig of basil on top and an inventive crust that wasn't made of biscuit crumbs (though I'm not actually sure what it was made of).

cwuNILx-b-1YbTLLiSXvzg.text: and I finally made it to Honey&Co. I have been following them on instagram before moving to London and for some strange reason, it took me 10 months to visit this shop and sample their food. We ordered the sharing platter brunch which included: greek salad, hummus, bread selection, 2 types of jam, labneh cheese, olives and pickles. With the same sharing platter comes 2 types of egg dishes for each (with bread and labneh on the side again) for which we ordered green shakshuka (amazing) and the egg plant/tahini dish on a pita bread that literally melts in your mouth. This platter is appx. £13 pp. The food was just really, really good. Portions are not huge but they are so filling (thanks olive oil) and full of flavour! I'm getting excited just thinking about my brunch and can't wait to be back to try their lunch and cakes!

gvdU59KOrZR5YT99kEFG0w.text: I guess it's time to update my review about Honey & Co and up my rating from 4 to 5 stars! Why? - They've delivered a more than solid performance over the last year and every time I come back, I get surprised yet again by their amazing food offerings. Just this morning I paid Honey & Co a visit and I was - as usual - greeted with a bright smile by Rachel: "Hi Uli! How are you?" Now, this is what I call amazing atmosphere and great "customer retention": there's only a handful shops in London, where people greet me with my name...but this is he most important reason for me to come back. Now, as I mentioned above, the food here at Honey & Co is also fantastic and I've yet have to eat something I didn't like. This morning, for example, I ate a lahme (some kind of Israeli breakfast pizza) accompanied by cardamom coffee. None of these I picked myself, but were recommended to me by Rachel: I simply don't like making decisions, so I am always happy for suggestions. All in all: both thumbs up! I love coming here!Note: it's almost impossible to make spontaneous dinner reservations and also the lunch spots are filling up way too quickly these days. I highly recommend swinging by for a delicious breakfast, though, as it is still quite peaceful and you will be able to read a newspaper or engage in a little chitchat with the staff.

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. At night...
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Georgian Lamb with plums
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Mediterranean prawns

JSB8Byc3IcdCs-WstE-zDA.text: This is a lovely little spot. Other reviews have called it unpretentious and, at the risk of repetition: it's a lovely little unpretentious spot.A lovely little unpretentious spot *serving up high levels of deliciousness*.I've never been her for dinner, so can't comment on the larger mains. More typical for me is a pop-by on Warren Street to pick up a baked good or 3. The chocolatey rich babka, sweet and yeasty. The orange blossom honey cake. The chock-full-of-poppy seed loaf. The cold cheesecake which is the much-talked-about dessert with delicious, deserved reason.Yesterday I stopped in for the most perfect little strawberry financier: made from almond meal and a tiny little spot of strawberry jam, and sporting a perfect berry hat...this was a winner, and a reminder that I'm still (deludedly!) clinging to summer. The space is small, but that adds to the warm vibe.Staff wonderful, limited - but excellent - range of options for breakfast and lunch (as mentioned: have not been here for dinner). Fresh juices. Friendly vibe. Yes, yes yes.Yelp note: Honey & Co cookbook on sale, too! As well as a shelf right when you come in with some preserves and granola and other things if you want to bring Honey & Co home with you...

1TK6NuOBJ6_f5ADxOFhDOw.text: Food was amazing, the service was equally as amazing which speaks volumes in the U.K. ...and there deserts was superb!

A7Cs3h5TgX8Y6varVEmWZw.text: Our group of seven was ravenous when we arrived at tiny Honey & Co. Thankfully, they were ready for us!The set dinner menu (£26.5/per person) took the guesswork out of our evening meal. It's a great way to go if you've got a group. You'll get a selection of bread with olive oil, homemade pickles and kalamata olives and a bunch of mezzes to shares like hot tomatoes with Manouri cheese and mint, hummus, falafel, lebeneh and watermelon and feta salad. And then everyone gets to pick their own main. I'd definitely recommend the lamb shawarma as a main. The meat was crazy tender and I enjoyed the elevated and deconstructed presentation (lamb in its own little pot with plenty of yogurt and pomegranate seeds on top, toasted pita in the middle, cabbage and tomates in a small bowl on the other side). And I wasn't the only one who enjoyed it, my colleagues enthusiastically dug into my plate too!If you're in the mood for a fresh take on food from the Middle East, you can't go wrong at homey Honey & Co.!

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Roasted octopus
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Lamb shawarma
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Menu

33w9YvbUtjPD3POS9nEYzg.text: Absolute delight!  Warm people, great food, fabulous dessert.  A must at my next visit to London!

QvOU3nMkg4_MgfTlkao9OA.text: We don't get this anywhere in the U.S.  This was just eye-openingly delicious. We came for breakfast and were so impressed by the wonderful flavors of cardamon, pistachios, fresh tahini, sweet sundried tomatoes...Favorites?- sticky pistachio pastry- sundried tomato tart- cold cheesecake (sorry, NYC's Juniors, this is now my fave)- yogurt with fruit and cerealWe arrived early around 8:15 and were promptly seated and served - no line.

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom

y2pe8KM7zlDfgGnRlgsbFQ.text: Great for breakfast of 3 or more persons sharing.  Small place but well worth the effort to visit early.

UGJHrvP_DZ_keomjRD--gw.text: Went here Friday for lunch... No lunch menu but we had the sprig set menu for £29. 1. The starters were delicious, especially the vegetables (tomatoes were so tasty!). I do agree with the other reviews in that they could serve a little more pitta bread.2. Mains- lamb tagine was not bad, just okay. I have made this at home and found that it was lacking the contrast of flavor some hopes to find in middle eastern good (slightly bland). My partner had the chicken shish- the chicken was cooked very well and was very good. The whole dish was great.3. Dessert- DON'T SKIP THIS! We had the walnut coffee cake and the plum coconut and almond. They were both deliciously perfect! 4. Service was fantastic! No complaints at all! **i don't think I would come back to have the full meal. This place is a one and done for me, however if I was in the area I would definitely come back for coffee and cake**

h0ISOygjNmxleg2njFzNXg.text: Ok, I admit. If I am welcomed at a venue by a BIG BIG smile of a staff it biases me towards a 5 star review really easily. But man... Honey & Co. made me rethink what I call a big smile!However, to the point - you can't go wrong with this place. It was FULLY booked 2 weeks ahead when me and my friends visited it. The only way to taste their food was to sit outside which we eagerly did. And I would do so again even during a winter of the century!Not being very hungry (and frankly - on a budget after 2 days in London) we did not go with an excellent £26/p.p. option of "a little bit of this, a little bit of that" which allows you to get some of all of their starters for share AND a main course for everybody.We (4 guys) settled on getting figs and falafel for starters and quails (x2), lamb meatballs and a chicken wrap with pomegranate.Oh yeah, when we were still trying to figure out what to order - a man walked out of the venue so we asked him about a recommendation. 'Everything is excellent.' was his response.You can imagine that we waited anxiously after such promise. Fortunately, this was not one of the "some that he's broken" (thank you Mr. Sting) and soon we were served meals that I would call exceptional. They were simple. They were not "overdone". They were just perfectly fitting this little, cosy spot.Writing about taste is like dancing about architecture (thank you Mr. Zappa) so try it for yourself, you won't regret it. And thanks to the owner (?), a heart-warming lady, I felt like the most important guest in their restaurant when talking to her.Well, if it's a job of a restaurant to amaze me - they've done it. Thank you, if I'm ever back in London, I'll visit you Honey & Co.P.S. You could have chosen a better beer for you offer though. :)

f6iBvBzHfbhpUaO6qXP76A.text: Amazing cheesecake with kaidaf pastry and greek thyme honey. Probably one of the best dessert in London I have ever tried! The cream is rich not over sweet. I wish there were more of the pastry as there was a huge dope of cheese above it. Need more to balance out the richness from the cream. Also a hint of thyme really differs this one to any other kind of cheesecake

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom

Idp0L0ehAlPXOGORTl-8eg.text: Tomato, pomegranate, vinegar, parsley salad with falafels was simple and tasty. The pistachio/tahini roasted carrots were great. Visiting from NYC and was impressed with the food.

K4hhqwfYaK0godbP3NTWUw.text: Loved this place so much I went back twice! It's a cute, quaint, and cozy restaurant. It's walls lined of preserved jams, the owners', cookbook and homemade granola.The staff were all incredible with a friendly demeanor, lovely warming smiles, and attentiveness.The food was perfectly balanced in flavor, texture, and visual elements. Each dish was filled with flavor yet kept subtle as to not be overpowering. It let the natural flavors play their role, not over compensating with seasoning or salt. Loved every bite!Get the green shakshuka. Definitely get the 'cheesecake'!

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Green shakshuka with pita instead of sesame bread
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom

DTVgDYdeE4Pf2afgVoAKbg.text: A friend and I went for brunch and really enjoyed it. We had the set brunch, which came with a great portion of starter yogurt / pita / etc, followed by a main of our choosing. Everything was very fresh and flavourful -- at times, I was amazed at how certain simple dishes could pack in so much taste. Service was generally good and prompt. The restaurant was rather small, so the servers' efficiency was key in ensuring all were seated and plates served on time. Ambience was cozy and very simple. Minimal decoration but in a way, added to this no-frills experience focusing on the flavours.

qhUFvaq0pW0sz1Obqv-Riw.text: One of my favorite brunch spots in London! Super cute, quaint, and cozy. On our visit to Honey & Co, my parents and I ordered the sabich and the shakshuka, both really good vegetarian dishes. However, dessert was easily the best part of the meal. I would come back again and again for that feta & honey cheesecake. The plum, pistachio, coconut & almond cake from the daily cake display was just as mind-blowing.

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. feta and honey cheesecake (6.50)
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. plum, pistachio, coconut and almond cake (4.70)
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. sabich (9.50) - roasted marinated mauve aubergine, tahini & dinosaur egg on homemade pitta

ru_IIHkiZ6Rmyo41M_NH9A.text: Ok so this place has been hyped for a very long time to me by multiple sources, one of my close friends even owns the cook book - I had to try it. I walked in with a friend for lunch - the tables are few and the space even less. We had booked lunch and we were sat down promptly. That was nice - I think it ended there. The menu didn't have much choice which can be both good and bad. I ordered the slow cooked lamb and my friend the aubergine dish from the mains. The environment was quite claustrophobic inside and I think we were both feeling a little nauseous with the variety of smells. Nothing really middle eastern about that. Having grown up in the Middle East I was excited to try the dishes. But they were most un-middle eastern like. The aubergine dish was bland as. It had a thick tahini crust which was curious but the dish lacked in flavour and wasn't appealing at all. The lamb came in a bowl - it had some sweet boiled plums inside with barberries. It was too sweet and very lamby. From memory the lamb I had growing up tend to be more dry and spiced not wet and sweet. Well at least the hummus and bread was decent (starters!)The irony of this experience is Honey & Co advertises itself with a seemingly assertive 'food from the Middle East' - and it felt like anything but. Overpriced as well.

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Lamb
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Aubergine
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom

Wu30nr34rlzZcMtu8zR3Aw.text: Definitely worth the stop! An A-OK destination.We ordered the Big Breakfast for two (menu attached.) You share bread, jam, labneh, fruit with granola, and fresh lightly pickled vegetables.You also order a "main" egg dish for each person at the table, so we ordered the green Shakshuka (with spinach instead of tomatoes) and the Phylas: cheese and labneh with egg in a phyllo pastry. To wash everything down, he had a latte and I had a Turkish coffee. I didn't taste the latte but I have to say that the Turkish coffee didn't quite pass muster. It was missing the thick rich mouthfeel and strong flavor. The food ingredients here are top-notch quality. Everything was fresh and presentation-wise, they're killing it. Gorgeous small dishes filled every square inch of our table. I felt like a KING! But somehow, this breakfast dishes didn't come together for me quite right. I'm a taster by nature--really love little bites of sweet to savory throughout a meal so I was surprised that this combination didn't leave the lasting impression I would have thought, knowing my taste preferences.The green Shakshuka was far too herby (you can only have so much raw dill) and was watery - diluting any flavors. The hummus, labneh and zataar were good, as was the fresh fruit in granola. The Phylas was okay, but I prefer a version of this I get at home at my favorite Turkish restaurant. I've seen the other pictures of the food here and wondered if maybe I ordered the wrong things? I'll definitely come back and try their other food!

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Breakfast menu
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Turkish coffee, green Shakshuka, tomato fatoush, Phylas, lightly picked veg with olives
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Hummus, zataar, latte, jam, olive oil, sugar on the table

U7-O51t54RZxMRS5_tM5DQ.text: OMG, this has to be one of the best eggplant dishes EVER. Surrounded by what I can only describe as sort of a lime fried rice, it had so many layers of flavor! The babka was also one of the finest I've had. What a great way to finish a meal. Bravo!

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. The best eggplant dish ever!
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Fantastically gooey babka.

qehuwksR9pwIwJ5tgaqkYw.text: My friend who is a major 'middle eastern' food fan has been here many times and wanted to come here on her birthday. I as an obliging friend readily agreed to come and enjoy the 'big breakfast' with her, which involves a dish of your choice plus an assortment of dips, salad and jam. The salad was incroyable!It's only my second time having shakshuka but as previously I really liked it.Service was good - almost ninja like refilling of the water bottle at one stage. Also everything came very promptly, we'd managed to order, be served and eat our entire feast within an hour but were also given plenty of time to sit and relax afterwards.

FC4UKoR7ntAtiq4q1dR65w.text: Yum! A truly delightful evening! When we arrived, we were pleasantly greeted and stepped through the menu. You can't go wrong with ordering the seasonal mezze set. We started our meal with a wide array of starter samplings, offering a colorful and tasty variety of items. Our main courses were artfully put together and tasted just as delicious -- a myriad of unique tastes melding together wonderfully.

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom

V0zdpoBdATENh-2cDNEvlw.text: The place isn't too big so not a place for big parties. But amazing food! Wish I'd found it earlier

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. The rabbit meat

WgwAMJbadHZc_NOE6jIK0w.text: Met a friend for lunch here. It's a tiny space and was busy on a Wednesday afternoon for lunch on a cold and rainy day in London. At my table we had the aubergine, meatballs, and lamb for entrees. For apps we had a pumpkin dish and falafel. The apps jumped off the table with their aesthetic but more importantly their taste. They were the stars of the show. The entrees again had a multitude of ingredients and flavors going on and were great. We all enjoyed it so much we all got dessert. I had traditional Turkish carrot cake  but one of my fellow diners had a truly traditional Turkish dessert that tasted like a chocolate cinnamon bun. Wow.

CC7_dm_e6UPwUWGGP2M_5A.text: You know how sometimes you wish you could rate a restaurant a 4.5 instead of a straight 4 or 5? Me too. This isn't one of those times. Honey & Co is a straight 5. I'd recommend getting the "Big Breakfast". The assortment of treats they bring out to start are simply perfection and the meal is, in my opinion, underpriced. I went on a weekday, but i'd imagine that they'd be busy on weekends so plan accordingly!

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom

wC-kuhYUWBDtiZjvcpfdJw.text: Honestly, one of my favorite restaurants I visited in London. The service was so friendly and informative. I wanted to be friends with my waiters!I went with one friend and the set menu was definitely the way to go. The standouts from the set menu at the time were the tahini and the roasted aubergine. I have seriously never tasted anything as flavorful as the aubergine! The combination of the tart pomegranate with the smoky flavor of the BBQ makes my mouth water just writing this. They have an entire display of tasty-looking desserts as well but all the waiters recommended the "life-changing" cheesecake and they were not joking. I've never had anything like it! If in London, definitely make this a stop on your trip and I promise you will be blown away. It's a very cozy space though, so I highly recommend calling ahead for a reservation.

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Aubergine is my new favorite food in life after this. The BBQ flavor was phenomenal!
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Set menu!
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. "Life-changing" cheesecake

pJrPWPwRj7QVlUwxd9G4Zw.text: This place is always busy but today was less crowded than usual. We got a seat at the bar by the window. Was not very impressed by the service. I think they must have lost out order or missed it. Waited 35-40mins for the fig loaf toast and the sausage rolls. The coffee was ok, was a little disappointed by the sausage roll pastry. It was a little stale. The fig loaf was pretty dense and sweet, but I liked it, nicely paired with orange marmalade.The waitress did apologize in the end for the slow service and gave us some cakes to make up for the delay. They also took off one of the coffees from the check. Appreciate the kind gesture.Overall it could have been a better experience, I'd probably give it another chance. Hopefully it'll be better :)

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Complimentary cakes
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. My latte and the window view

NPF2IHNhf59IJzFhU1xMww.text: Yummy pastries. I got a few tartlets to take home to share - strawberry and pistachio/apricot/creme. Both made with almonds instead of wheat flour. Really moist with lots of flavor. I'm totally biased though as I've been drooling over their baking book for a while and couldn't wait to come and check them out in person. Did not disappoint.Didn't get a chance to try out their savory food.

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. tiny inside!
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom

Isr0b9iIOKKx4mlNOGhFSg.text: A little pricey and since I was only eating by myself, I had the Yemeni style falafels (4 with side of hummus and cucumbers for £7.5 and comes with a nice side of hummus) and their cold cheesecake on a Kadaif pastry with raw Essex honey (£6.5) which was highly recommended in multiple reviews. Of those two, I'm giving the 5 stars because of the cheesecake. It's not your ordinary cheesecake and is amazing in every way possible. It comes with blueberries and almond slices on top of a crunchy shell and there's just something absolutely amazing about it. The falafels weren't bad either but there was nothing crazy about them and for the portion and price, I'd probably just pass next time. The waiters were very friendly and even offered blankets to those of us sitting outside because it was a little chilly. The shop isn't big though so if you're going in a group, I'd suggest making reservations.

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Cold cheesecake, Kadaif pastry, raw Essex honey(6.5)
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. falafel with hummus and cucumber salad - 7.5 pounds

GIgFUyzJBO9OmAlMuKK-Ew.text: This is a very good mediterranean restaurant but I have to say didn't left me with a memorable impression. We went for dinner and I think it's best at lunch. The place is very very tiny, not the best setup for a catch up with a friend.Mezze platter to start was really really good and filling. So filling I couldn't eat my main, let along try a cake. Service was really nice and friendly and they even pack my main for me to take home.Good thing to know, they do take away (even if it looks like a sit-down restaurant): you just need to call 20min before coming to collect your lunch.

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Mezze starter for 2: more than enough for an entire dinner

W9Ktye5hR4x2Mv-C9VRUZQ.text: Before starting in on the food, I have to reiterate that Honey and Co has some of the nicest waitstaff in London!  They strike the perfect balance of warm and attentive, without a hint of condescension or abruptness.  Even on a busy Friday night, without a reservation, I was welcomed like a friend, and slotted into one of their front window-facing counter seats.  Every detail of the meal and the surroundings had been carefully and lovingly planned, down to how the napkin is folded with a clothespin, and how the dishes were strewn with fresh herbs.  The hummus was absolutely superior, and it could be easy to stuff yourself with a mezze assortment of starters before the mains arrive.  The chicken shish platter was huge, and also had technicolor flavors going on.  This is a obviously popular restaurant, and for good reason.  I can't think of another recent dining experience where I've left feeling so happy.

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Glorious hummus and pitta
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom. Chicken shish with freekah and herbs

QaMfuxdyDmKIlJkYZ-eCsQ.text: Delicious Delicious delicious. I went for a dinner and I was suggested to try poached pears salad fir a starter and stew lentil with eggs which was excellent.  And I tried orange blossom iced tee which tasted a bot weird like a candle but nice and refreshing at the same time. I wish I tried their kanafa cheese cake but i was planning to try have a dessert somewhere else. But I will definitely be coming again for the food next time am in London.

photos.caption: Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Honey & Co - London, United Kingdom

Ak-VkfY0hoMJ-2T7XOQJrQ.text: Absolutely amazing food. The lamb schwarma (don't expect the typical schwarma if you've been to the Middle East, but a slowly cooked spiced meat falling off the bone deliciousness) is heavenly! Their breads are all house baked and to die for, their salads, house made labneh, cakes, tarts, biscuits.....ALL house made and amazing. So much love and care is put into the preparation of their food. Lovely!
